instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO: What is PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO? PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
Have another 00244 logic board, except this one isn't showing any sign of life. Also no sign of liquid damage.

<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v.

I've compared resistance at F3050 with a known good board and it checks out. Any suggestions as to where to start with this type of failure?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message: CPU getting hot on this one too? If no, check if you have 5 or 20 volts on DC in first as well as what voltage you get on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> is the main dc line from j9600. Also <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is also 0V. 

<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> does initially spike to almost 1v then drops to 0v when the charger is first plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
Check resistance to ground (diode mode) on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and all power rails of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.
Also test the same at F7040 and L6995.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.02v

Diode mode check of all power rails of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, F7040 and L6995 comparable to a know good board. There's about .020v difference between boards on some of the readings. 

While checking around, don't know if this means anything, but <SIGNAL>TPA508SMC_DEV_SUPPLY_L</SIGNAL> has about 2.5v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.02v"
Is that diode mode, or voltage reading?
Don't post end "V" for diode mode readings...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message: Voltage mode. Ill post the diode mode values late today.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
Charger gets protected, so no voltage apllied to board.
There is no reason to check voltages on the board; just diode mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
Value to the left is with positive multimeter probe to ground pad. Value to the right is with multimeter ground probe to ground pad.


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.461/OL

<SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0.592/OL

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL>  - 0.424/1.40

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_VIN</SIGNAL> - 0.586/1.536

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> - 0.3172/1.9

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 0.4831/1.5

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.5281/1.6

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> - 0.5787/OL

<SIGNAL>P1V2S5SW_HSMUX_EN</SIGNAL> - 0.77/1.44

<SIGNAL>PP1V8D_UPC_XA_LDO</SIGNAL> - 0.491/1.4

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
There is no short, nor even low value on any rail.
Check for continuity between F3050 and USB-C connector; should be 4 pins, on the charger side.
If OK, change <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>: Not Powering up, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> - 0v
threads.message:
Continuity check was good.

Yep, <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> fixed it. Thanks a lot guys for the assist. Macbook now has life again.
